Well, I've got it running.  It takes a LONG time.  Computationally intensive 
is putting it mildly.  And that's after trimming it down to 146 nodes and 
thousands (as opposed to millions) of connections.  I found that the tuning 
of the parameters plays a big part in how long it takes to settle down.  
Once I get the x,y coordinates determined for each node, I need to create a 
graphical display of the results, so I can visually inspect it.

Can one of the SVG experts offer me a brief tutorial of what the SVG would 
look like to just draw a bunch of lines and then do a bunch of labeled 
circles at the virtexes?


>From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
>Reply-To: neat@yahoogroups.com
>To: neat@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [neat] Re: Network Visualization
>Date: Tue, 06 Apr 2004 09:36:43 -0000
>
>John, I think this is a very interesting idea, and could be a good way
>to graph a neural network, or any large network or topology for that
>matter.  The one question I have is about the computational
>complexity:  Does computing the net force on a node requires comparing
>it to every other node?  I wasn't clear how the net"repulsive
>proximity force" is computed?  I imagine if it's n^2 in the number of
>nodes it might be prohibitive?  In any case I think this is a clever
>approach.
>
>However, I should note that using Mat Buckland's approach or one like
>it should be sufficient for determining vertical node placement in
>NEAT, since over the course of evolution it is possible to always know
>what level/layer a new node should be in based on the level/layer of
>already existing nodes around it.  Still, there is the question of
>horizontal placement, which actually could still benefit from an
>approach what you are proposing.  (Though I think Mat had a horizontal
>split value as well...I need to look up how that was computed)
>
>I'd be very interested to see net visualizations generated through
>your method.
>
>ken
>
>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
> > This is mildly off-topic, and yet relevant...
> >
> > I have some data I want to visualize.  The nature of the data is a
>network
> > or mesh of associations.  It is far more complicated than the
>networks that
> > NEAT generates.  Thus, the solution for visualizing this data might
>be a
> > good way of visualizing a complex NEAT network, too.  So I thought
>perhaps
> > the people on this list might have some interest in a contributing
>to a
> > solution to this problem.
> >
> > The origins of the data is the dictionary.  Specifically
> > dictionary.reference.com and thesaurus.reference.com.
> >
> > I started with a word.  It really doesn't matter which word, but I
>started
> > with 'intelligence'.  I query the dictionary and thesaurus entries
>for that
> > word and parse the results.  I get a list of words that appear in
>those two
> > pages.  I save that list as the list of 'associations' for that
>word.  Now
> > for each of those words (which I have not already processed), I
>repeat the
> > process.  Virtually no matter what word I start with, I end up with
> > basically the whole dictionary.  Then I prune those associations to
>include
> > only those that are reciprocal.  That is, word A references B, and B
>also
> > references A.  An example would be Tree and Bark.  This pruning
>makes the
> > data SIGNIFICANTLY smaller, but still pretty large.
> >
> > Now I would like to present the data as a visual 'mesh' or network.
>  It
> > would help me to 'see' the connections.  I want to minimize the
>lengths of
> > the connections so that related words appear close to one another.
> >
> > Here's what I had in mind.  Load the data into memory.  Randomly
>assign x,y
> > positions to each node.  Then treat every direct connection as an
>attractive
> > force, and treat physical proximity as a repulsive force that falls
>off with
> > the square of the distance.  For each time step, calculate the net
>force.
> > Then reposition the nodes based on that net force.  Repeat until the
>net
> > movement approaches zero.  Then save the positions of everything
>and
> > generate a visualization of it.
> >
> > For NEAT, I thought that you could add an additional 'force' that
>is an
> > extra repulsive force between input and output nodes.  Then, the
>input nodes
> > would tend to cluster towards one side, and the output nodes on the
>other,
> > with a delicate balance forming in the nodes in between.
> >
> > Any thoughts?
> >
> > -- John
> >
> >
>
>
